question: Ugh. Caden! That's weird. The phone stops ringing.
answer: Is something wrong with my poop? I didn't! What's wrong with me?! A cellphone rings in the other room.

question: Honey, I have to get this. You're going to be fine.
answer: But, Mommy -- Adele runs into --

question: I don't feel well.
answer: Daddy, my poop is green. Caden enters the bathroom, looks into the bowl at the green feces and smeared toilet paper. He seems freaked out. Am I going to be okay?

question: Of course, honey.
answer: Did you have green poop when you were little?

question: Will there be a scar?
answer: Probably. It looks like a mudflap.

question: I prefer there not be a scar.
answer: That fellow is annoying. He's in here every week. Like clockwork. The off-screen patient continues to whimper. The doctor finishes his work on Caden. There. I think that should -- He looks at Caden's eyes, turns off the bright lamp and looks again. He turns the lamp back on and looks once more.

question: What? The doctor feels Caden's pulse, then listens to his heart. He presses hard against the glands in Caden's neck.
answer: Changes in bowel movements?

question: A little more yellow than usual. What?
answer: I'd like you to see an ophthalmologist.

question: A neurologist?
answer: What? No, an ophthalmologist. I said, ophthalmologist.

question: Oh. The doctor stares blankly at Caden for a long moment, then looks suspiciously in Caden's ears.
answer: No, it's Friday, honey. So what exactly did he say?

question: My pupils weren't properly dilating and, um, not doing the opposite ...
answer: Constricting.

question: What are you doing? Jesus.
answer: I'm trying to explain plumbing.

question: Well, stop it. It's okay, honey.
answer: No, honey, you're fine.

question: You don't have to worry, baby. You don't have blood.
answer: Well, I don't think you should tell her she doesn't have blood.

question: Caden, stop it! Olive cries. Adele coughs. Caden stares out the window. It's dark, but his pupils are pinpricks.
answer: Thanks for getting me in right away. The doctor touches Caden's eye repeatedly with a small probe. Is it the bump to the head?

question: Thanks for getting me in right away. The doctor touches Caden's eye repeatedly with a small probe. Is it the bump to the head?
answer: No. Could be. But I think we need to get you to a neurologist. Nothing urgent.

question: A neurologist?
answer: Yes, a brain expert.

question: I thought maybe you said urologist. Why do I need to see a neurologist?
answer: For a look-see. The eyes are part of the brain, after all.

question: That's not true, is it?
answer: Why would I say it if it weren't true?

question: It just doesn't seem right.
answer: Like morally correct? Or right as in accurate?

question: I'm not sure. Accurate, I guess.
answer: Hmm. Interesting. The doctor writes in Caden's chart.

question: It's too late in the game to be having these problems, David. You're sure you're okay?
answer: Yeah? I was trying something different. I was crashing differently. Ambivalently.

question: I saw that. I like it. Caden meets Tom at the foot of the stage. Behind them a group of technicians are lifting the wall and trying to re- set it. Claire primps in the bureau mirror. Try to keep in mind that a young person playing Willy Loman thinks he's only pretending to be at the end of a life full of despair. But the tragedy is that we know that you, the young actor, will end up in this very place of desolation.
answer: Okay.

question: Great. Let's try it again. Why don't you get cleaned up, Tom, and we'll go again. Tom exits. Caden rubs his temples, then heads to the back of the house, pulling out his cell phone. He exits the theater.
answer: I just heard the death of the salesman.

question: In more ways than one. In search of elusive signal.
answer: Signal's good here, oddly. She pats her lap in a friendly manner.

question: That is odd.
answer: I know! Cell phones, they're crazy!

question: Dr. Heshborg said I should see Dr. Scariano. My pupils don't work.
answer: I keep reading the first line. It's a good line, I think. But I don't know much about literature.

question: Maybe you should read the first line of another series of books.
answer: I'm trying to better myself, Caden. Recommend me something. You're a genius; you must've read nearly a dozen books.

question: Exactly twelve. Have you read Kafka?
answer: Um, I've read his name. A lot! I swear!

question: His whole name?
answer: Okay, not his entire name. Heinz? If you say so, I will. Can't wait till Wednesday. I'm so excited to see it.

question: I hope you like it.
answer: It's pretty impossible that I won't, you know. I mean... She trails off, shrugs. They smile at each other. Caden exits. Hazel looks at her book, re-reads the first sentence.

question: Maybe not as much as I had hoped. That's a terrible thing to say.
answer: There are no terrible things to say in here. Only true and false.

question: I feel alone sometimes. I feel exhausted. Can I say something awful?
answer: Yes. Please do.

question: It's a nightmare in there.
answer: The car crash?

question: Well... not only.
answer: Sorry. So I'm reading The Trial.

question: Yeah? You like?
answer: Love. I'm such an idiot for not knowing about this book. It's famous, it turns out.

question: You're not an idiot. Pause.
answer: Then you say, in fact, you're very bright, Hazel. And I love your eyes.

question: Then what do I say?
answer: I can't say what then you say.

question: Why?
answer: Cause it's dirty. A whistling noise turns their heads. In the distance a man with an unopened parachute is plummeting. Oh my God! Jesus! They watch as the man falls behind a building. A scream. A screech of brakes. He's gotta be dead. Right?

question: Can I piss in your sink?
answer: Um, yeah, I guess. Caden pisses in the sink in the corner of the studio. His urine is amber. He finishes and peeks over Adele's shoulder, through the magnifying glass at the painting. It's an amazingly detailed and angrily colored painting of a woman in a state of profound despair, screaming to the heavens, while standing in a field of flames.

question: It's gorgeous, Ad.
answer: Thanks. How was rehearsal?

question: Awful. We have five hundred and sixty lighting cues. I don't know why I made it so complicated.
answer: It's what you do.

question: Yeah. Anyway, we got through it. I think you'll be impressed.
answer: Caden, listen, I'm really sorry. I just can't go tonight. I'm sorry. I've got to get two canvases ready to ship. By tomorrow. I know it sucks.

question: Oh boy, oh boy.
answer: Willy!

question: It's all right, I came back.
answer: Why? What happened?

question: No, nothing happened.
answer: You didn't smash the car, did you?

question: I said nothing happened. Didn't you hear me?
answer: Don't you feel well?

question: I'm tired to death. I couldn't make it. I just couldn't make it, Linda.
answer: Where were you all day? You look terrible.

question: I got as far as a little above Yonkers. I stopped for a cup of coffee... maybe it was the coffee.
answer: What?

question: I suddenly couldn't drive any more. The car kept going off onto the shoulder, y'know? The audience is rapt. Caden relaxes.
answer: Ugh, I hated myself tonight. Plus I'm so bloated and enormous.

question: Yeah. Absolutely. Sorry. I have a bit of a headache.
answer: I just want to thank you for everything. You've been absolutely brilliant and it's going to be miserable going ahead without you.

question: I'll be around. I'll check in. She gets teary, gives him a kiss on the cheek.
answer: God, I'm such a baby. She just looks at him and smiles and nods. I'm going to get drunk, that's what.

question: Ok, Claire. She backs away and gets lost in the crowd. Caden massages his temples. Suddenly Hazel is next to him.
answer: I figured I'd better get in fast.

question: Hey!
answer: I loved it! And, by the way, Claire is trouble. And not terribly bright. Caden laughs. Just wanted you to know the word on the street.

question: So you liked it?
answer: Are you kidding? I cried for like fifteen minutes after. I loved every minute of it. Except Claire. I thought she was weak.

question: Easy on the eyes.
answer: Oh, Caden, not you, too. What I want to know is why she started crying in her last monologue, right after she had the line, 'I can't cry for you Willy...'? Where's el wife-o?

question: Had to work. Her Berlin show is in two weeks. We're going to spend like a month there.
answer: Ah.

question: Ah.
answer: Ah.

question: Choo!
answer: Hooray! We've still got it!

question: Y'know... bothered. Horny.
answer: And me with a station wagon and all. Could be dangerous. You're absolutely zero fun.

question: You know I wish I could.
answer: Jesus, I like you. I'm going.

question: You're not staying for the reviews?
answer: I know it's brilliant. I don't need some dope with elbow patches telling me. She smiles, gives him a hug, and heads toward the door. You're not going to make it, baby.

question: I've always loved this house.
answer: The sellers are very motivated now.

question: It's a scary decision. I never thought I'd buy a house alone. But, y'know, I'm 36, and I wonder what I'm really waiting for.
answer: It's a good size though, twenty-two hundred square feet. Not including the partially-finished basement

question: I like it, I do. But I'm really concerned about dying in the fire.
answer: It's a big decision, how one prefers to die. Would you like to meet my son? Derek?

question: Hi. It's late.
answer: Maria came over to keep me company and we lost track. I'm sorry I missed the play. But I got everything done here. How'd it go?

question: We're a hit. Reviews are great. New York Times said it was brilliant to cast young actors as Willy and Linda.
answer: I'll see it tomorrow. Tonight! Adele and Maria laugh.

question: Are you stoned?
answer: A little. I don't know. Y'know? I mean, are you happy with it?

question: Yeah. Love to know what you think.
answer: It doesn't matter what I think.

question: What's wrong with your face, Daddy?
answer: It's pustules. It's called sycosis. Spelled differently than psychosis, but it sounds the same.

question: I don't know what that means.
answer: Well, there's two different kinds of psychosis. They're spelled differently. P-s-y is like if you're crazy and s-y is like these things on my face.

question: You could have both though.
answer: I could. But I don't.

question: Okay, pretend we're fairies. I'm a girl fairy and my name is ... La-ru...lee. And you're a boy fairy and your name is Teeteree.
answer: Ok.

question: What's my name again?
answer: La-ru-lee.

question: No. I said ... La-ru-la...ay. Pretend we fight each other. And I say stop hitting me or I'll die. And you say okay, but you're fibbing. And you hit me again.
answer: Okay.

question: Okay. Let's go. Hit me. They pretend to hit each other. Olive makes hissing and roaring noises. She stops. Okay. You have to stop hitting me now or I will die.
answer: Okay. He stops.

question: No! Pretend you're fibbing! Remember? He mock hits her again. She falls. Now I have to die.
answer: I don't want you to die.

question: But I have to.
answer: But I'll miss you.

question: I have to. And you'll have to wait a million years to see me again. Caden tears up at this and tries to conceal it. And I'll be put in a box. And all I'll need is a tiny glass of water. And lots of -- tiny pieces of pizza. And the box will have wings, like an airplane.
answer: Where will it take you?

question: Is that your entire frame of reference for relationship problems?
answer: No. I don't know. It's a stressful time. Our shows. The whole health thing.

question: Oh, you're fine.
answer: I think I might have arthritis. Adele continues to talk on the phone.

question: No, I know. Exactly. Caden picks up the newspaper. It's dated May 25th, 2006. He flips through, finds the obituaries and starts to read. Ok. All right. Yeah. Ok, bye. Adele hangs up the phone, looks at the paper.
answer: My joints are stiff. Who was that?

question: Maria.
answer: Right. It's been three hours since you spoke.

question: Caden, I think I want to go to Berlin with just Olive. Caden looks up. I think it would be good for us. Silence. Caden's father appears in the doorway.
answer: Can I ask you a question, Ad? She looks up at him. Have I disappointed you somehow? She starts to cry, hugs him.

question: We should get a drink. Be fun.
answer: Be weird.

question: I like weird. I like you. See? He doesn't say anything. Anyway. I don't want to make you uncomfortable. I just thought it would be a fun diversion. Okay, I do want to make you uncomfortable. You can, Cade. You can!
answer: I have an appointment.

question: Crease.
answer: What do you mean?

question: It's just a word. Don't get all bent out of shape. Jeez.
answer: I won't. Sorry.

question: I'm afraid I'm going to die. They don't know what's wrong with me. I want to do something important. While I'm still here.
answer: That would be the time to do it, yes. I have a book that might help you get better.

question: Who wrote it?
answer: Wow. Yes, wow. Wow indeed. She hands Caden the very thick book. He flips through it, catching words and snippets here and there That's forty-five dollars. Wow.

question: Hey! Thanks for meeting me. He points to his nose. She wipes at the soot on hers.
answer: God, I'm delighted. Thought you'd never ask. You did ask, right?

question: I didn't want to be alone.
answer: Who does?

question: I'm going through some things.
answer: You want to tell me about it?

question: I can't really. But I'm meditating and running and taking vitamins. Cutting out sugar. I can't really say any more. It's ...
answer: Ok. Tell me something else.

question: You tell me something. Oh. I've cut out wheat.
answer: Um, I bought this really nifty sweater today. On sale. Fifty dollars reduced from three hundred!

question: Adele is only on vacation.
answer: She hasn't called you since she left. You've left countless messages. It's been a year.

question: It's been a week.
answer: I'm going to buy you a calendar. Caden rips a cocktail napkin into little pieces.

question: Okay, just for one drink. Hazel smiles and stands. She scoops up the torn napkin pieces and puts them in her purse.
answer: Scraps for my scrapbook. Caden watches her ass as she turns to leave.

question: I really can't drink very much because of my condition.
answer: Caden's mysterious condition. Well, have one sip, anyway.

question: Did you put something in it?
answer: Would you like me to have? A little love potion, perhaps?

question: Sure, why not?
answer: If that's what it takes, consider it done. Poof! Love potion number

question: It's good. She takes a sip of her drink. Caden drinks some more of his.
answer: Does it make you want to kiss me?

question: Yeah. Kind of.
answer: Tell me why?

question: Um, I feel a lot of longing.
answer: Hmm. Beg a girl, why dontcha.

question: What?
answer: I'd like you to beg me on your knees for a kiss. Just for fun. Dumbly, Caden gets down on his knees.

question: Why am I doing this?
answer: For fun, baby.

question: You'll help me forget my troubles?
answer: Oh, kiddo, you don't even know.

question: I have a wife.
answer: You have me. And I adore you. What? What is it?

question: Hello? Hello? Who is this?
answer: It's Caden!

question: Ellen?
answer: Caden! I can't wait to see you and Olive on the 12th. um... I went someplace without you tonight, Ad. I went some place you couldn't come with me. I'm sorry.

question: What? Who is this? Oh, I have to go. There's a party. I'm famous!
answer: Oh. Ok. Great. Have fu -- The connection is lost. Caden sits there, looks at the 2007 tax form in front of him, goes into convulsions. He manages to grab the phone, his hand flopping all over the dial. I'm sick.

question: A theater piece. Something big and true and tough. Y'know, finally put my real self into something.
answer: That's wonderful. God bless! I guess you'll have to discover your real self. Right?

question: Yeah, I mean, yeah. Oh, I wanted to ask you, how old are kids when they start to write?
answer: Varies.

question: Could a four year old keep a diary?
answer: Listen, there's an absolutely brilliant novel written by a four year old.

question: Aww. Cute.
answer: Hardly. Little Winky is a virulent anti-Semite. The story follows his initiation into the Klan, his immersion in the pornographic snuff industry and his ultimate degradation at the hands of a black ex-convict named Eric Washington Jackson Jones... Johnson... Jefferson, with whom he embarks on a brutal homosexual affair.

question: Wow. Written by a four year old?
answer: Azpiazu killed himself at five.

question: That's horrible.
answer: He would've written so much more had he lived. They developed a method -- some software -- to determine what he would've written had he lived to ten, twenty, thirty, etcetera.

question: Is that possible?
answer: Which part?

question: Any of it. Why did he kill himself?
answer: I don't know, why did you?

question: What?
answer: I said, why would you?

question: I'm looking for a Christmas present for my daughter. Something pink. Yes. That's good. The idea is to do a massive theater piece. Uncompromising, honest. I don't know what it is yet or how to do it, but it'll come. It'll reveal itself.
answer: Huh. Pause.

question: Heres what I think theater is
answer: What are you doing?

question: Salivating.
answer: Huh.

question: So I was wondering if you'll help.
answer: In your box office?

question: No. Like as my assistant.
answer: I'm not sure I can work with you, Caden. I'm kind of angry.

question: I just want to normalize it, Hazel. I think we'd have fun together. He swallows some food then concentrates. She watches him. I miss you. He concentrates some more. She stares at him. I'm digesting.
answer: It's really disturbing.

question: You are so obnoxious!
answer: You're so obnoxious.

question: Yeah, well, you find it awfully charming. My obnoxiousity.
answer: Obnoxiousity is not a word.

question: You don't want to cross me.
answer: Don't I?

question: No. Because you like me so much.
answer: True. I like your obnoxiousity.

question: And my use of the word "obnoxiousity."
answer: Yes.

question: Yes. You're delicious in your acquiescence. Claire enters, looks for Caden. She spots Hazel first. Hi, Claire.
Hazel.
answer: Of course. Hazel. I knew that! Duh! The box office.

question: Yes, I'm the box office.
answer: How are you?

question: Wonderful! You?
answer: Fine, thanks. I was supposed to meet Caden here. You know Mr. Cotard, right?

question: That was awkward.
answer: Yeah, I guess. Caden steals glances at Hazel, chatting animatedly, throughout his conversation with Claire. He hears occasional snippets.

question: Let's talk about our project. I'm so excited about it.
answer: Really? Why?

question: I just think it's... brave. I feel like I'm going to be part of a revolution. I keep thinking Artaud. I keep thinking Krapp's Last Tape. Grotowski, for Christ's sake!
answer: I don't know what I'm doing.

question: ... theater can we take as a country? Y'know? Knowing that you don't know is the first and most essential step to knowing. Y'know?
answer: I don't know.

question: So tell me what you want from me?
answer: Hmm?

question: From my character.
answer: Oh. Well, we'll build it over time together. Find a real person, maybe, to model it after.

question: That Hazel girl is kind of interesting, maybe. As a model.
answer: Um, yeah. Something to think about. Sure. Although -- No. I have these health issues.

question: My mother died last night.
answer: My God. I'm so sorry. What are you doing out?

question: Ugh, I couldn't deal with my sisters. It's like living in a Heironymous Bosch painting.
answer: Oh. I see. Well, um, What happened to your mother, if I could ask? I mean, God, that's an awful thing to ask. I'm sorry. I don't mean to -- It's just that, I'm --

question: Oh, this is me. No, it's okay. She fell. Slipped in her bathroom. Hit her head. It actually split in half. Horrible. They stop at a small hatchback with a cow painted on it.
answer: In half?

question: I don't know how it's Freudian.
answer: Y'know. Like "meet"? To meet?

question: Oh. Well, I'm sorry about your mother. In half?
answer: It's okay. It's life. It's -- Claire's face contorts into a horrifying, paralyzed grimace.

question: What is it? What? She weeps silently, with gaping mouth. Caden awkwardly embraces her. She remains stiff. Do you want me to drive you home? She shakes her head "no" over and over. Then she looks in at her reflection in the car window.
answer: Sometimes when I cry, I watch myself so I can remember how it looks for future roles. It's horrible. I hate myself.

question: It's okay. Everyone does that. It's -- is there anything I can do?
answer: I used to be a baby.

question: I'm so sorry.
answer: I was a baby girl with hair of spun gold, the prettiest baby anyone had ever seen. One day the townsfolk, who were jealous of my beauty, decided to steal me away.

question: He said, "There is one more thing. You must never tell anyone what you promised me. If you do, you will die." So I used my new power to kill all the townsfolk. Horrible, humiliating deaths. I was reunited with my family. And I lived happily ever after, doing only good with my new powers. Caden cries and rests his head on her thigh. Why are you crying, honey?
answer: I'm so in love with you. Claire smiles, strokes his hair. I have problems, Claire. I'm still attached to my wife. I have also -- I have also -- feelings for Hazel. I've left them behind. I've gone somewhere without them. I'm guilty of so much.

question: It's okay. We'll be fine. You're with me now. We'll be good.
answer: There will be no other before you. Okay, hold it. We're not really -- I think we need to work on your characters individually. We need to investigate, to really discover the essence of each being. Davis, I'll start with you. Caden walks off with Davis. Claire seethes.

question: She's 36. Works in a theater box office. She had acting aspirations but lacked the confidence to pursue them. Her life is passing by. She is alone. She's old and ugly --
answer: I think you should pick another subject. Other than Hazel.

question: Sacred ground?
answer: No. It's just. I don't feel like there's enough there. Claire thinks for a moment.

question: I suppose not. She is limited. Okay. There's this single mother who lives downstairs. I find her really deep and sad.
answer: Tell me.

question: I'm looking for Adele Cotard. I'm her husband. You're here, too?
answer: I live with Adele and Olive and Gunther und Heinz and Uschi and Britt. I'm everyone's nanny.

question: Maria, I can't believe Adele got her tattooed like that. I mean --
answer: I did that. Olive's my project.

question: She's a four year old!
answer: She's almost over eleven now. She's my muse. I love her. Caden stares at her for a moment, then lunges. He punches her repeatedly as she tries to get away. She throws a punch which connects with the side of his head and knocks him down. She hurries off.

question: What'd you do to my family? What'd you do to my daughter?
answer: Screw you, Caden. Faggot! FAGGOT! She turns down an alley. Caden, a half-block behind, hurries to the alley. She's gone. He walks through, looking for her. It's dark. Trash cans and garbage. He spots an unopened box next to the trash. It's pink with a picture of a nose on it. Caden drops to his knees and weeps. No tears come out. His eyes are dry and red. He pulls a vial of artificial tears from his pockets and moistens his eyes. Suddenly his breathing becomes wildly erratic.

question: Dr. Williams, that was your last patient for the day.
answer: Jennifer, let's stop this charade.

question: I don't know what you're talking about, Doctor.
answer: The chemistry between us is palpable. You and I both know that.

question: Dennis... I can't.
answer: Why not? It's the way God made us.

question: I can't because Jerry came back last night.
answer: Jerry, but he's dead. I'm certain of that because...

question: Because what? Because what, Dennis?
answer: Because I'm certain, that's all. Ariel sits in a highchair and plays with a bowl of Cheerios. She is about two and a half.

question: I can't argue with further testing.
answer: Ok, you're a doctor, right? Am I dying? Can you tell me that?

question: No.
answer: No, you can't tell me?

question: Um, yeah. For a while now.
answer: What are you doing in New York?

question: Oh. Im here with Derek and the boys. Mini-vacation! You know.
answer: The boys?

question: How old?
answer: Five. Twins. Robert and Daniel and Allan.

question: Ah. Yes.
answer: Oh. Derek took them to Natural History. So I could shop.

question: Ah.
answer: Nice to see you, Caden. How are things?

question: Yknow. I was with Claire. We have a daughter, but we're separated now. How about with you?
answer: Good. The kids are wonderful. I have a great job at Lens Shapers.

question: Great. You wear a lab coat?
answer: Its so good to see you. I should run. I want to get some shopping in. Were meeting back at the hotel at three. Then sushi!

question: Okay. Good seeing you, Hazel. Hazel smiles and waves and turns to head into the store. Caden watches after her.
answer: Yes?

question: It's me. I want to come back. I want to take care of you and Olive. Ariel. There's silence then the door opens. Claire is crying.
answer: I just want you to love us. Caden hugs her. Ariel hugs Caden's good leg. It's 3:30. For crying out fuck. Caden answers the phone.

question: Hello? What's wrong? Okay. Okay. Caden hangs up. Claire kisses Caden's neck. My father died.
answer: Oh, baby.

question: His body was riddled with cancer. He didn't even know. He went in because his finger hurt.
answer: It's okay, baby. It's going to be okay. Let me make you feel better. Claire begins kissing her way down Caden's chest.

question: Yeah, I guess that's what happens when you have a kid with somebody else. You having sex with her?
answer: Yes. Of course. I mean, what --

question: I have to go. I'm sorry about your dad. That's awful news.
answer: Hazel, please, I can't bear it if you go.

question: I have to. I'm going out. I have to get ready. Everything's fine.
answer: I need to use a cane now.

question: The cry of the North American Caden.
answer: I'd just like a little sympathy.

question: I'll save my sympathy for the eighty million people with avian flu, the Tsunami victims in Puerto Rico, the countless millennia dead from... how fucked it all is.
answer: Millennia dead? What? And since when do you care about anything?

question: I care every day about things! I care about us! ... Y'know?!
answer: Hazel! Hazel and Derek turn.

question: Oh, honey, I can't anymore. It's okay. I'm okay.
answer: I don't want you to be okay. I mean, I do but it rips my guts out.

question: I'll always be your friend. I'll help you through any way I can.
answer: I'll help you through, too.

question: Caden, I'm fine. I have Derek.
answer: I won't settle for anything less than the brutal truth. Brutal! Each day I'll hand you a scrap of paper. It'll tell you what happened to you that day. "You felt a lump in your breast. You looked at your wife and saw a stranger." Etcetera.

question: They fired me. I caused an outbreak of conjunctivitis. I didn't wash my hands. I had pink eye hands! Pink hands!
answer: Oh God.

question: I didn't wash my hands! I'm a stupid cow! I don't have anything to show for being on this planet. And this fucking private Christian school is killing us. It's not cheap. It's Derek's thing. I don't believe in that shit. Y'know? Try to be a good person. That's all there is. I'm sorry. I'm talking too much. Do you have anything for me, Caden? Sammy Barnathan? Sammy Barnathan stands. He is the gaunt man we've seen following Caden. Hazel leads him to Caden. Caden stands.
answer: Good. Tell me why you're here.

question: When it's ready. I was thinking of calling it Simulacrum. What do you think?
answer: I don't know what it means.

question: How about The Flawed Light of Love and Grief?
answer: I'm not sure. Sammy jots something in his book. I'm going to work in my journal. You guys need anything?

question: Start, huh? Caden chuckles.
answer: She left us. You know that better than anyone. Except me.

question: Amazing artist though. The best living artist. There's no one who stares the truth in the face like she does. A sweet pussy, too. Caden looks at Sammy, confused.

question: Oh. I read it.
answer: Anyway, I don't know where she is. A strange dirigible flies very low overhead.

question: Maybe she's got a sublet in New York. Maybe the Met's doing a retrospective. Maybe, baby. He hands Caden a slip of paper.

question: I want to follow you there and see how you lose even more of yourself. Research. For the part. Partner.
answer: Have a good night. He picks up his pace, trying to be casual about it. He arrives at 31Y, glances over and sees the old person knocking feebly on a door down the hall.

question: Have a good night. He picks up his pace, trying to be casual about it. He arrives at 31Y, glances over and sees the old person knocking feebly on a door down the hall.
answer: Oh yes. I see. Old Person #2 squints over at Caden.

question: What?

question: Ok. Thank you. Old Person #2 turns and heads back down the hall to Old Person #1, whose nose has started to bleed.

question: I don't know. Like mold? I don't know. Like mold and ... cleaning products? Like you're menstruating? I don't know! I don't like that guy you got to play you.

question: I think you need to fire him. Caden hands her a scrap of paper. Oh, fuck you. I'm forty-five years old. I don't want to do this shit anymore.

question: I got an offer to do Needleman in a Haystack and I'm going to take it. I want you out of the apartment. The real one. You can keep this one. Claire heads down the stairs.

question: Will, I need you to build this. Caden hands Will shots of the exterior and interiors of Adele's building and of apartment 31Y. Hazel, what do you think of this title

question: You're weirdly close to what I've visualized for this character.

question: You don't like him, do you?

question: I'm me. You don't need someone to remind you of me.

question: I'm fun.
answer: Oh, sweetie. No, you're not. Caden's cell phone rings. He answers it.

question: Was my father standing with us?
answer: I don't know what he looks like.

question: He's dead. He looks dead, I guess.

question: A little moustache? She shrugs.

question: I asked Hazel but she was busy tonight and you're the next best thing. I mean, it isn't that you're the next best thing but because you play her, it feels comforting. Does that make sense? Although the thing is offstage you're nothing like her. You play her very well though. Did Hazel mention what she was doing tonight because I called her house before we left and her husband said she wasn't going to be back till late and I thought that was weird because she told me Philip was sick.
answer: She's going to dinner with Sammy. Don't forget your phone.

question: Thank you, Yammy. Caden takes the phone and limps off. Hey. What you up to? Why didn't you tell me that before?

question: It mostly makes me sad that it doesn't make you sad.

question: I want you to be sad that we had something really special and it's going away!

question: He has stories about me!
answer: Caden, I know everything about you and it's all adorable. I love you and I always will. So don't worry. I gotta go, I'm there. Hazel hangs up. Caden stands there for a minute.

question: Did you always want to be an actress?

question: Is that true?

question: I thought someone would've cleaned it up.

question: Is there no end to your pussy kissing?

question: That's such a romantic response. I'm touched.

question: Right. What?

question: I know how to do it now. There are nearly thirteen million people in the world. Try to imagine that many people! None of those people is an extra. question: We could get a place together. We could get a loft.

question: Yeah. I miss Olive. And the other one. The retarded one.

question: You can't cause someone to kill himself. He was troubled.
answer: I'm so ashamed of myself. Caden walks over to her and touches her shoulder. Oh, Caden. I wish we had this when we were young. And all the years in between. So many years, so fast.

question: God. You're just perfect.

question: I'm embarrassed. I just want you to know it's not you. And it's not me. It's the medication. They are tender and quiet and intensely focused. The smoke in the room is dense. answer: It's okay. It's different crying this time. I can tell. I'm crying, too. And I cried last time. After you left. I never told you. But I cried, too. Caden kisses her again.

question: I have a title. The Obscure Moon Lighting an Obscure World.

question: Forgive me but no longer remember English. Speak German? I'm dying, as I'm sure Maria told you. The flower tattoos have become infected and they're dying. So I am, as well. This is life. Olive pulls down her hospital gown a bit to show Caden the now sickly and decayed flower tattoos.

question: Maria gave me reason to live once you left. The flowers defined me.

answer: For abandoning you to be have anal sex with my homosexual lover Eric.

question: My love. I know how to do the play. It'll take place over the course of one day. The day will be the day before you died, the happiest day of my life. I'll be able to relive it forever. I need a Caden for my Hazel.

question: Um...
answer: I know it would be non-traditional casting, but I think I'm right for it. I think I understand Caden.

question: I don't understand him.
answer: Caden Cotard is a man already dead, living in a half-world between stasis and antistasis. Time is concentrated and chronology confused for him. Up until recently he has strived valiantly to make sense of his situation, but now he has turned to stone.

question: Okay. That sounds good.
answer: She's right? I didn't see that at all. I saw it all as more hopeful. Any thoughts for today's rehearsal? Huh.

question: The title is about a lot of things. You'll see. It's about a lot.
answer: Yes. I don't see what that has to do with anything.

question: Filled? You mean...? Yes?
answer: ... touched by the sadness of Adele's neighbor. So close to death. Reminds me of granny. I should really call her. Remember how Granny Bascomb bounced me on her knee pretending to be a horsie. I loved that so much. Say thank you to Adele's neighbor.

question: Thank you.
answer: Now say, have a very good day.

question: Have a very good day.
answer: ... miss him. Why did he have to get bored with me? Everyone gets bored with me. I'm not very bright. And since I put on that weight, I don't get the looks I used to. It's not that bad. Lots of people have it worse. I've got a job and place to stay. Adele is nice to me. And so smart and talented. I don't understand her artwork, but that's just me. I wish I'd gone to college. I feel stupid around educated people like Adele. Eric was too smart for me, too. We didn't talk at all near the end. I'd try to tell him about my day and he'd get this far away look in his eyes. I kind of felt sorry for him; he seemed so miserable with me. I guess -- Caden drifts off to sleep.

question: Eric. Caden looks over. No note from Adele. He gets out of bed, glances in the mirror, seems surprised by his reflection.
answer: My period is late this month. I wonder what's going on. I'm bloated. I wish it would come. I can't believe she said that to him! She's a slut, anyway. He sticks a bookmark in the book, puts it on the night table, turns off the light, and lies on his back with his eyes open. Maybe I can ask Adele for a raise. It's been three years. I do a good job. God, I'm so tired tonight. I'm getting old. I'm lonely here. Get up. Look at the night table for a note from Adele. Caden gets up and glances at the night table. A type-written Look shocked. Weep. Caden looks shocked, then weeps. Go into the kitchen and -- The voice stops. Caden stops. He waits. Nothing. He takes out the earpiece and looks at it, shakes it, then slips it back in his ear. Nothing. He waits. In the distance he hears wailing and gun shots.
